awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed Building Education Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) site will advance STEM education by engaging teachers in building science research topics including indoor air quality, lighting effectiveness, thermal comfort, and energy efficiency. Multiple domains of building science will be utilized to engage teachers in STEM disciplines in a way that offers Education for Sustainability as a unifying and energizing theme and Systems Thinking as the overarching learning objective. Participating teachers will be equipped with the capabilities and instruments to experiment with air quality, lighting systems, and energy use in their respective school buildings as hands-on and applied STEM-based teaching modules. This will be accomplished through offering immersive RET experience for three cohorts of teachers across urban and rural school districts and Intermediate Units and the engagement of 30 teachers in developmental research experiences and curriculum integration practices that link research, student engagement, and STEM/Systems Thinking education outcomes. This research will advance methods in Education for Sustainability and as a result, is expected to attract women and underrepresented minority students into STEM fields. Linkages to state and national partners will enable broad dissemination and adoption of Education for Sustainability principles and the living laboratory strategy as instruments for advancing STEM education as well as global challenges in energy and human health. The project will lead to shareable teaching modules that can be adapted by science, math, physics, and chemistry teachers.

This RET site will demonstrate direct linkages between teacher-engaged research, sustainability focused teaching contexts, and STEM learning outcomes. Teacher-led and student engaged data collection and analysis as an innovative and meaningful context will be evaluated for its impact on student STEM self-efficacy and student ability to use data and evidence to effectively solve problems and optimize systems, environments, interfaces, and devices. This research will also evaluate Education for Sustainability as a strategy for cultivating teacher capacity to design effective instructional methods in systems thinking.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

In 2019, Pennsylvania State University received a $600,000 RET site award entitled ?RET Site: Building Education.?

Intellectual Merit: High school and middle school educators participated in the Building Education RET site program, where they underwent training, gained research experience, and received mentoring in the diverse field of sustainable building systems. Each year, a collaborative environment brought together researchers, engineering faculty, and teachers for seven-week-long summer workshops. During the initial six weeks, teachers engaged in an authentic research project, collaborating with scientists and engineers four days a week and benefiting from professional development provided by CSATS science education faculty on the remaining day. In the seventh week, teachers prepared their technical research posters.The project team facilitated hands-on, experimental, and numerical activities to enhance discovery and learning. Teachers involved in the Building Education RET Site contributed substantially to the ongoing research efforts. Some of the examples are:

1- Assessed the impacts of natural and artificial light on students' alertness, focusing on daylighting, shading devices, and circadian lighting.

2- Developed a simple Arduino-based sensor module for on-site measurement of window properties.

3- Created computational models that establish connections between innovative smart building control technologies and energy, economic, and environmental performance indicators. During this project, teachers gained experience in coding and data processing using MATLAB and/or Python.

4- Acquired knowledge in setting up IoT sensors, developing building performance models, running parametrically generated building geometry simulations, and analyzing resulting data to identify trends and desired outcomes.

5- Utilized immersive technologies such as Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), eye tracking, and wearable sensors within a VR simulator to evaluate the effectiveness of VR-based training scenarios in enhancing students' learning.

An external evaluator interviewed research supervisors and teachers to gather qualitative feedback on the project's effectiveness. The following excerpts are taken from the evaluation reports: Collaborating with teachers as researchers presents an excellent opportunity to enhance the quality of research and make it more applicable to real-world issues. Participants recommended that an ideal approach may involve a blend of online and face-to-face interactions tailored to the team's individual requirements.

Broader Impacts

The participants from 10 states across the US were predominantly women, making up 73% of the total attendees, while over half of the represented schools were identified as economically disadvantaged institutions. Project activities were extensively disseminated through technical publications, our website, and media outreach. Several of our teachers participated in the Partners in Science conference, specifically designed for teachers with research experience in academic or industry settings. Moreover, all the teachers engaged in the Building Education program designed classroom research projects for their students based on their research. Some implemented these projects during their academic year professional development, stemming from their participation in our program.

Project teachers? success stories include creating lab experiments and developing curricula to integrate sustainable building systems in teaching and learning. Some examples of teacher success stories follow.

Ms. Minkler engaged students in a study correlating lighting conditions to students' alertness and attention. She started by explaining general lighting concepts and how light affects human vision and circadian rhythms. After getting familiar with the non-visual effects of light on the human body, students participated in an experiment to compare the impact of electric lighting and daylighting on their heart rate variability (HRV) and the melatonin level in their bodies. HRV data indicates human attention, while melatonin level indicates how alert a person is. The experiment was conducted on two days: on the first day, students were exposed to daylighting only, while on the second day, they were exposed to electric lighting (Fluorescent). The results demonstrated the significant impact of natural lighting on student alertness and melatonin levels.

Mr. Bernhardt has created an 8-week section on iPhone/Arduino development. Students wired a model home with an Arduino, Wi-Fly, lights, and a servo (acting as a garage door opener). They then worked on developing an iPhone App to open and close the garage door and turn lights on and off. His Game Programming course now develops games for iPhone and Androids in addition to web-based games. The Lynbrook School District also approved a full-year Robotics course, which includes both Lego and Tetrix robots to be programmed in RobotC.

Mr. Mayne, who teaches statistics, used the data created from the RET research as a theme throughout the year whenever relevant. For example, his AP class started with sampling methods. He discussed how they would sample from the over 2000 historical structures in Beirut after the 2020 ammonium nitrate explosion. For the non-AP classes, he just finished describing and displaying categorical data. He believes this experience has been life-changing for him. He said, It kindled a fire within me to pursue a master's degree in applied statistics. I would love to continue working within a similar field doing the statistical part of research?
